Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: TUES: Vertical Integration of Concepts and Laboratory Experiences in Biometrics Across the Four Year Electrical and Computer Engineering Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is a collaborative effort involving Rowan University, Bucknell University, and Tennessee State University that is vertically integrating conceptual knowledge and laboratory experiences in biometrics across the curriculum. Vertical integration refers to a series of laboratory exercises in a given topical area that start as well-structured experiments at the lower levels and proceed to increasingly complex, open-ended design projects at upper levels of the curriculum. The investigators intend to create a national model by developing multi-year curricular material that allows course content in separate classes to be naturally interconnected. The project is providing educational experiences that are training future system designers prepared to deal with the complexity, implementation, and performance evaluation of a variety of biometric methods (face, speech, iris, signature, and fingerprint). Students are also gaining a better knowledge of policy, ethical, and societal impact issues of biometrics. The team is disseminating their material and results through web postings on the project's websites and on the Connexions website (http://cnx.org/), through technical and educational conferences and journal articles, and through a faculty workshop. The project includes outreach to a local community college and to K-12 school teachers. Both internal and external evaluator are using pre- and post-survey data and the results of rubric-based scores on student work with experimental and comparison groups to monitor progress toward project goals. Broader impacts include the broad dissemination, the community college and K-12 outreach, and the focus on the social aspects of the technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A significant shortcoming of common practices in engineering education is that "most curricula (effectively) require students to learn in unconnected pieces" [1]. Relationships between concepts that are taught in disparate courses are often not perceived by the students. Faculty and instructors generally hope that at least some of the students are able to recognize such vital relationships by themselves -yet- it is frequently observed that the desired connections are simply not realized [1].

The theme, importance, and motivation for this project is, thus, derived from a need to foster a more integrative approach to engineering education. Important engineering concepts must become recognizable for the students not only between disparate courses but also across the temporal progression of the curriculum (i.e. from freshmen to seniors). We have developed multi-year curricular materials that allows course content in separate classes to be naturally interconnected via laboratory exercises that are associated with a central theme. Biometrics, the science of recognizing and authenticating people using their physiological features, was chosen as the central theme. Biometrics is well suited for this task because of its inherently interdisciplinary character and its increasing importance in the solution to certain societal problems (e.g. national security). We implemented and evaluated the proposed approach in a naturally diverse multi-institution setting, comprised of Rowan University (a public state university), Bucknell University (a private university), Tennessee State University (an HBCU) and Gloucester County College (a community college). An in-depth evaluation of all proposed activities was achieved by implementing target versus control group surveys, biometric specific surveys, statistical tests, concept inventory tests, rubric based scores and summative evaluations.

The developed materials comprise a series of laboratory exercises that start as well-structured experiments at the lower levels of the curriculum and proceed as increasingly complex open-ended design projects at upper levels of the curriculum. An experiment in an upper level course builds upon a previous experiment performed in a lower level course. The series of vertically-integrated and problem-oriented laboratory experiments cut across artificial course boundaries and introduced fundamental, contemporary and multidisciplinary biometric system concepts. We provide public access to the developed materials through our project web-site [2]. Results of our studies were published in refereed journal and conference papers. Some materials have, also, become part of a new senior elective course in biometrics at Rowan University.

Additional outcomes of the project work included an NSF sponsored faculty/instructor workshop at which the developed materials were presented as well as a biometrics introduction module at the high school level. The goal of the high school model was to enrich the learning/teaching experience of high school students and teachers in the STEM field and to excite high school students to take up a career in engineering.

Overall, our assessments and evaluations indicate that the developed methods and modules are indeed achieving a significant improvement in our student's ability to recognize concept relationships across disparate courses and the curriculum as a whole. An interest in biometrics as a course of study was increased. Our students began to comprehend biometrics from a systems perspective, they began to understand the importance of vertical integration, and we were able to foster a better understanding of the political, ethical, and societal impact of biometrics in our students.

References:

[1] J. Bordogna, "Next Generation Engineering: Innovation Through Integration", Keynote Address, NSF Engineering Education Innovators Conference, April 8, 1997.
